Based on the context provided, Alexander Pushkin was a young man who wrote epigrams, letters, and planned an autobiography. He was prolific and had ideas for works emerging months in advance. In 1814, he published his first poem, "To a Poet-Friend," under a pseudonym. His breakthrough came in 1815 when he read his poem "Reminiscences in Tsarskoe Selo" at an exam, impressing Gavriil Derzhavin. After graduating from the Lyceum in 1817, Pushkin became a civil servant but was more interested in literary pursuits. He joined the "Arzamas" literary circle and became part of St. Petersburg's literary society.

In summary, Alexander Pushkin was a Russian writer and poet who gained recognition for his literary works during his youth.
